summary: Brockway McMillan was a member of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB) during the period covered by these documents (1963-1964). The documents consist of meeting minutes and agendas of the PFIAB. McMillan's specific contributions or actions are not detailed in the summaries provided, but his presence at these meetings indicates his involvement in advising the President on foreign intelligence matters. The topics discussed during these meetings included intelligence activities related to Cuba, covert operations, signals intelligence (SIGINT), the National Reconnaissance Program, and the Soviet Bloc threat. The documents suggest McMillan was involved in high-level discussions and reviews of intelligence operations and policies during this period.
significance: Based on the provided documents, Brockway McMillan's significance in the JFK assassination context is indirect. As a member of the PFIAB, he was involved in advising the President on foreign intelligence matters, including those related to Cuba and covert operations. While the documents do not explicitly link him to the assassination, his role in the PFIAB places him within the broader context of intelligence activities and policy discussions during that era.
